perturbation.original_text: "Heritage shall produce the products described on Schedule A and Schedule A-1 attached hereto, as may be amended by the Parties hereafter from time to time (the "Products," each individual unit of Product "Unit"), for Premier at [***] Heritage's or Heritage's wholly owned subsidiary, Jasper's facilities (the "Facilities"). [***], except that, notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, [***]."
perturbation.changed_text: "Heritage shall produce the goods described on Schedule A and Schedule A-1 attached hereto, as may be amended by the Parties hereafter from time to time (the "Products," each individual unit of Product "Unit"), for Premier at [***] Heritage's or Heritage's wholly owned subsidiary, Jasper's facilities (the "Facilities"). [***], except that, notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, [***]."
perturbation.explanation: The term "products" was replaced with "goods." While seemingly similar, the UCC defines goods very specifically, potentially narrowing the scope of what Heritage is obligated to produce beyond the original intent of 'Products' as defined elsewhere in the contract with accompanying schedules A and A-1 that list specifically what must be made. This creates ambiguity and a potential legal contradiction regarding the scope of manufactured items covered by the agreement.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) - Definition of Goods

perturbation.original_text: "During the Term, Premier shall have the right (but not the obligation) to order from Heritage quantities of Products in excess of [***] and provided Heritage has the capacity and the ability to produce such additional quantities of Products, Heritage agrees to produce such additional quantities per the pricing and terms on Schedule C."
perturbation.changed_text: "During the Term, Premier may request from Heritage quantities of Products in excess of [***] and provided Heritage feels like it has the capacity and the ability to produce such additional quantities of Products, Heritage may agree to produce such additional quantities per the pricing and terms on Schedule C."
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'shall have the right' to 'may request' weakens Premier's ability to order. Replacing 'agrees to produce' with 'may agree to produce' gives Heritage complete discretion. This fundamentally alters the obligation to fulfill orders beyond the minimum, creating a contradiction in the original agreement's intention of guaranteed production capacity.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law - Obligation to Fulfill Orders

perturbation.original_text: "All Products manufactured, packaged and delivered by Heritage or Jasper under the terms of this Agreement shall conform to the specifications supplied to Heritage by Premier as listed on Schedule A and/or Schedule A-1, which Schedules may from time to time be modified by Premier in writing (the "Specifications"), shall conform to Post Holding's Quality Expectations Manual attached hereto as Schedule E, and shall conform in all material respects to samples previously supplied to Premier by Heritage."
perturbation.changed_text: "All Products manufactured, packaged and delivered by Heritage or Jasper under the terms of this Agreement shall generally conform to the specifications supplied to Heritage by Premier as listed on Schedule A and/or Schedule A-1, which Schedules may from time to time be modified by Premier in writing (the "Specifications"), shall endeavor to conform to Post Holding's Quality Expectations Manual attached hereto as Schedule E, and shall reasonably resemble samples previously supplied to Premier by Heritage."
perturbation.explanation: Replacing 'shall conform' with 'shall generally conform', 'endeavor to conform' and 'reasonably resemble' introduces significant ambiguity. The original text creates a standard that is supposed to be clear cut. These changes weaken the requirements for product quality and introduce vagueness that could be disputed in court, contradicting the clear, enforceable obligation implied in the original. It also contradicts the intention of Schedules A, A-1, and E, which are supposed to give a clear definition on the specification of the product.
